trans-unit.source: Scheduler concepts, terms, and entities | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Scheduler concepts, terms, and entities | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Azure Scheduler concepts, terminology, and entity hierarchy, including jobs and job collections. Shows a comprehensive example of a scheduled job.
trans-unit.target: Azure Scheduler concepts, terminology, and entity hierarchy, including jobs and job collections. Shows a comprehensive example of a scheduled job.

trans-unit.source: The following table describes the main resources exposed or used by the Scheduler API:
trans-unit.target: The following table describes the main resources exposed or used by the Scheduler API:

trans-unit.source: Resource
trans-unit.target: Resource

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Cloud service
trans-unit.target: Cloud service

trans-unit.source: Conceptually, a cloud service represents an application.
trans-unit.target: Conceptually, a cloud service represents an application.

trans-unit.source: A subscription may have several cloud services.
trans-unit.target: A subscription may have several cloud services.

trans-unit.source: Job collection
trans-unit.target: Job collection

trans-unit.source: A job collection contains a group of jobs and maintains settings, quotas, and throttles that are shared by jobs within the collection.
trans-unit.target: A job collection contains a group of jobs and maintains settings, quotas, and throttles that are shared by jobs within the collection.

trans-unit.source: A job collection is created by a subscription owner and groups jobs together based on usage or application boundaries.
trans-unit.target: A job collection is created by a subscription owner and groups jobs together based on usage or application boundaries.

trans-unit.source: It’s constrained to one region.
trans-unit.target: It’s constrained to one region.

trans-unit.source: It also allows the enforcement of quotas to constrain the usage of all jobs in that collection.
trans-unit.target: It also allows the enforcement of quotas to constrain the usage of all jobs in that collection.

trans-unit.source: The quotas include MaxJobs and MaxRecurrence.
trans-unit.target: The quotas include MaxJobs and MaxRecurrence.

trans-unit.source: Job
trans-unit.target: Job

trans-unit.source: A job defines a single recurrent action, with simple or complex strategies for execution.
trans-unit.target: A job defines a single recurrent action, with simple or complex strategies for execution.

trans-unit.source: Actions may include HTTP requests or storage queue requests.
trans-unit.target: Actions may include HTTP requests or storage queue requests.

trans-unit.source: Job history
trans-unit.target: Job history

trans-unit.source: A job history represents details for an execution of a job.
trans-unit.target: A job history represents details for an execution of a job.

trans-unit.source: It contains success vs. failure, as well as any response details.
trans-unit.target: It contains success vs. failure, as well as any response details.

trans-unit.source: At a high level, the scheduler and the service management API expose the following operations on the resources:
trans-unit.target: At a high level, the scheduler and the service management API expose the following operations on the resources:

trans-unit.source: Capability
trans-unit.target: Capability

trans-unit.source: Description and URI address
trans-unit.target: Description and URI address

trans-unit.source: Cloud service management
trans-unit.target: Cloud service management

trans-unit.source:
GET, PUT, and DELETE support for creating and modifying cloud services

https://management.core.windows.net/{subscriptionId}/cloudservices/{cloudServiceName}
trans-unit.target:
GET, PUT, and DELETE support for creating and modifying cloud services

https://management.core.windows.net/{subscriptionId}/cloudservices/{cloudServiceName}

trans-unit.source: Job collection management
trans-unit.target: Job collection management

trans-unit.source: GET, PUT, and DELETE support for creating and modifying job collections and the jobs contained therein.
trans-unit.target: GET, PUT, and DELETE support for creating and modifying job collections and the jobs contained therein.

trans-unit.source: A job collection is a container for jobs and maps to quotas and shared settings.
trans-unit.target: A job collection is a container for jobs and maps to quotas and shared settings.

trans-unit.source: Examples of quotas, described later, are maximum number of jobs and smallest recurrence interval.
trans-unit.target: Examples of quotas, described later, are maximum number of jobs and smallest recurrence interval.

trans-unit.source:
PUT and DELETE: https://management.core.windows.net/{subscriptionId}/cloudservices/{cloudServiceName}/resources/scheduler/jobcollections/{jobCollectionName}

GET: https://management.core.windows.net/{subscriptionId}/cloudservices/{cloudServiceName}/resources/scheduler/~/jobcollections/{jobCollectionName}
trans-unit.target:
PUT and DELETE: https://management.core.windows.net/{subscriptionId}/cloudservices/{cloudServiceName}/resources/scheduler/jobcollections/{jobCollectionName}

GET: https://management.core.windows.net/{subscriptionId}/cloudservices/{cloudServiceName}/resources/scheduler/~/jobcollections/{jobCollectionName}

trans-unit.source: Job management
trans-unit.target: Job management

trans-unit.source: GET, PUT, POST, PATCH, and DELETE support for creating and modifying jobs.
trans-unit.target: GET, PUT, POST, PATCH, and DELETE support for creating and modifying jobs.

trans-unit.source: All jobs must belong to a job collection that already exists, so there is no implicit creation.
trans-unit.target: All jobs must belong to a job collection that already exists, so there is no implicit creation.

trans-unit.source: https://management.core.windows.net/{subscriptionId}/cloudservices/{cloudServiceName}/resources/scheduler/~/jobcollections/{jobCollectionName}/jobs/{jobId}
trans-unit.target: https://management.core.windows.net/{subscriptionId}/cloudservices/{cloudServiceName}/resources/scheduler/~/jobcollections/{jobCollectionName}/jobs/{jobId}

trans-unit.source: Job history management
trans-unit.target: Job history management

trans-unit.source:
GET support for fetching 60 days of job execution history, such as job elapsed time and job execution results. Adds query string parameter support for filtering based on state and status.

https://management.core.windows.net/{subscriptionId}/cloudservices/{cloudServiceName}/resources/scheduler/~/jobcollections/{jobCollectionName}/jobs/{jobId}/history
trans-unit.target:
GET support for fetching 60 days of job execution history, such as job elapsed time and job execution results. Adds query string parameter support for filtering based on state and status.

https://management.core.windows.net/{subscriptionId}/cloudservices/{cloudServiceName}/resources/scheduler/~/jobcollections/{jobCollectionName}/jobs/{jobId}/history

trans-unit.source: There are two types of jobs: HTTP jobs (including HTTPS jobs that support SSL) and storage queue jobs.
trans-unit.target: There are two types of jobs: HTTP jobs (including HTTPS jobs that support SSL) and storage queue jobs.

trans-unit.source: HTTP jobs are ideal if you have an endpoint of an existing workload or service.
trans-unit.target: HTTP jobs are ideal if you have an endpoint of an existing workload or service.

trans-unit.source: You can use storage queue jobs to post messages to storage queues, so those jobs are ideal for workloads that use storage queues.
trans-unit.target: You can use storage queue jobs to post messages to storage queues, so those jobs are ideal for workloads that use storage queues.

trans-unit.source: At a basic level, a scheduled job has several parts:
trans-unit.target: At a basic level, a scheduled job has several parts:

trans-unit.source: The action to perform when the job timer fires
trans-unit.target: The action to perform when the job timer fires

trans-unit.source: (Optional) The time to run the job
trans-unit.target: (Optional) The time to run the job

trans-unit.source: (Optional) When and how often to repeat the job
trans-unit.target: (Optional) When and how often to repeat the job

trans-unit.source: (Optional) An action to fire if the primary action fails
trans-unit.target: (Optional) An action to fire if the primary action fails

trans-unit.source: Internally, a scheduled job also contains system-provided data such as the next scheduled execution time.
trans-unit.target: Internally, a scheduled job also contains system-provided data such as the next scheduled execution time.

trans-unit.source: The following code provides a comprehensive example of a scheduled job.
trans-unit.target: The following code provides a comprehensive example of a scheduled job.

trans-unit.source: Details are provided in subsequent sections.
trans-unit.target: Details are provided in subsequent sections.

trans-unit.source: As seen in the sample scheduled job above, a job definition has several parts:
trans-unit.target: As seen in the sample scheduled job above, a job definition has several parts:

trans-unit.source: Start time (“startTime”)
trans-unit.target: Start time (“startTime”)

trans-unit.source: Action (“action”), which includes error action (“errorAction”)
trans-unit.target: Action (“action”), which includes error action (“errorAction”)

trans-unit.source: Recurrence (“recurrence”)
trans-unit.target: Recurrence (“recurrence”)

trans-unit.source: State (“state”)
trans-unit.target: State (“state”)

trans-unit.source: Status (“status”)
trans-unit.target: Status (“status”)

trans-unit.source: Retry policy (“retryPolicy”)
trans-unit.target: Retry policy (“retryPolicy”)

trans-unit.source: Let’s examine each of these in detail:
trans-unit.target: Let’s examine each of these in detail:

trans-unit.source: The "startTime” is the start time and allows the caller to specify a time zone offset on the wire in <linkText>ISO-8601 format</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The "startTime” is the start time and allows the caller to specify a time zone offset on the wire in <linkText>ISO-8601 format</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The “action” is the action invoked on each occurrence and describes a type of service invocation.
trans-unit.target: The “action” is the action invoked on each occurrence and describes a type of service invocation.

trans-unit.source: The action is what will be executed on the provided schedule.
trans-unit.target: The action is what will be executed on the provided schedule.

trans-unit.source: Scheduler supports HTTP and storage queue actions.
trans-unit.target: Scheduler supports HTTP and storage queue actions.

trans-unit.source: The action in the example above is an HTTP action.
trans-unit.target: The action in the example above is an HTTP action.

trans-unit.source: Below is an example of a storage queue action:
trans-unit.target: Below is an example of a storage queue action:

trans-unit.source: The “errorAction” is the error handler, the action invoked when the primary action fails.
trans-unit.target: The “errorAction” is the error handler, the action invoked when the primary action fails.

trans-unit.source: You can use this variable to call an error-handling endpoint or send a user notification.
trans-unit.target: You can use this variable to call an error-handling endpoint or send a user notification.

trans-unit.source: This can be used for reaching a secondary endpoint in the case that the primary is not available (e.g., in the case of a disaster at the endpoint’s site) or can be used for notifying an error handling endpoint.
trans-unit.target: This can be used for reaching a secondary endpoint in the case that the primary is not available (e.g., in the case of a disaster at the endpoint’s site) or can be used for notifying an error handling endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Just like the primary action, the error action can be simple or composite logic based on other actions.
trans-unit.target: Just like the primary action, the error action can be simple or composite logic based on other actions.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to create a SAS token, refer to <linkText>Create and Use a Shared Access Signature</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to create a SAS token, refer to <linkText>Create and Use a Shared Access Signature</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Recurrence has several parts:
trans-unit.target: Recurrence has several parts:

trans-unit.source: Frequency: One of minute, hour, day, week, month, year
trans-unit.target: Frequency: One of minute, hour, day, week, month, year

trans-unit.source: Interval: Interval at the given frequency for the recurrence
trans-unit.target: Interval: Interval at the given frequency for the recurrence

trans-unit.source: Prescribed schedule: Specify minutes, hours, weekdays, months, and monthdays of the recurrence
trans-unit.target: Prescribed schedule: Specify minutes, hours, weekdays, months, and monthdays of the recurrence

trans-unit.source: Count: Count of occurrences
trans-unit.target: Count: Count of occurrences

trans-unit.source: End time: No jobs will execute after the specified end time
trans-unit.target: End time: No jobs will execute after the specified end time

trans-unit.source: A job is recurring if it has a recurring object specified in its JSON definition.
trans-unit.target: A job is recurring if it has a recurring object specified in its JSON definition.

trans-unit.source: If both count and endTime are specified, the completion rule that occurs first is honored.
trans-unit.target: If both count and endTime are specified, the completion rule that occurs first is honored.

trans-unit.source: The state of the job is one of four values: enabled, disabled, completed, or faulted.
trans-unit.target: The state of the job is one of four values: enabled, disabled, completed, or faulted.

trans-unit.source: You can PUT or PATCH jobs so as to update them to the enabled or disabled state.
trans-unit.target: You can PUT or PATCH jobs so as to update them to the enabled or disabled state.

trans-unit.source: If a job has been completed or faulted, that is a final state that cannot be updated (though the job can still be DELETED).
trans-unit.target: If a job has been completed or faulted, that is a final state that cannot be updated (though the job can still be DELETED).

trans-unit.source: An example of the state property is as follows:
trans-unit.target: An example of the state property is as follows:

trans-unit.source: Once a Scheduler job has started, information will be returned about the current status of the job.
trans-unit.target: Once a Scheduler job has started, information will be returned about the current status of the job.

trans-unit.source: This object is not settable by the user—it’s set by the system.
trans-unit.target: This object is not settable by the user—it’s set by the system.

trans-unit.source: However, it is included in the job object (rather than a separate linked resource) so that one can obtain the status of a job easily.
trans-unit.target: However, it is included in the job object (rather than a separate linked resource) so that one can obtain the status of a job easily.

trans-unit.source: Job status includes the time of the previous execution (if any), the time of the next scheduled execution (for in-progress jobs), and the execution count of the job.
trans-unit.target: Job status includes the time of the previous execution (if any), the time of the next scheduled execution (for in-progress jobs), and the execution count of the job.

trans-unit.source: If a Scheduler job fails, it is possible to specify a retry policy to determine whether and how the action is retried.
trans-unit.target: If a Scheduler job fails, it is possible to specify a retry policy to determine whether and how the action is retried.

trans-unit.source: This is determined by the retryType object—it is set to none if there is no retry policy, as shown above.
trans-unit.target: This is determined by the retryType object—it is set to none if there is no retry policy, as shown above.

trans-unit.source: Set it to fixed if there is a retry policy.
trans-unit.target: Set it to fixed if there is a retry policy.

trans-unit.source: To set a retry policy, two additional settings may be specified: a retry interval (retryInterval) and the number of retries (retryCount).
trans-unit.target: To set a retry policy, two additional settings may be specified: a retry interval (retryInterval) and the number of retries (retryCount).

trans-unit.source: The retry interval, specified with the retryInterval object, is the interval between retries.
trans-unit.target: The retry interval, specified with the retryInterval object, is the interval between retries.

trans-unit.source: Its default value is 1 minute, its minimum value is 1 minute, and its maximum value is 18 months.
trans-unit.target: Its default value is 1 minute, its minimum value is 1 minute, and its maximum value is 18 months.

trans-unit.source: It is defined in the ISO 8601 format.
trans-unit.target: It is defined in the ISO 8601 format.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the value of the number of retries is specified with the retryCount object; it is the number of times a retry is attempted.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the value of the number of retries is specified with the retryCount object; it is the number of times a retry is attempted.

trans-unit.source: Its default value is 5, and its maximum value is 20\.
trans-unit.target: Its default value is 5, and its maximum value is 20\.

trans-unit.source: Both retryInterval and retryCount are optional.
trans-unit.target: Both retryInterval and retryCount are optional.

trans-unit.source: They are given their default values if retryType is set to fixed and no values are specified explicitly.
trans-unit.target: They are given their default values if retryType is set to fixed and no values are specified explicitly.
